questions.question: What is the primary assumption behind the Naive Bayes classifier?

answers.a: Features are dependent on each other
answers.b: Features are independent given the class
answers.c: It requires a large amount of training data

explanations.a: Naive Bayes assumes independence between features, making this incorrect.
explanations.b: Correct! Naive Bayes assumes that features are independent given the class label.
explanations.c: Naive Bayes performs well even with small datasets, so this is incorrect.
explanations.d: Naive Bayes is a probabilistic classifier, making this statement false.

questions.question: Which preprocessing step is NOT typically required before training a Naive Bayes model on text data?

explanations.b: Lowercasing ensures consistency in word comparison.
explanations.c: Correct! Sorting words alphabetically has no impact on classification.
explanations.d: Removing stopwords helps reduce noise in text data.

questions.question: Why do we split the dataset into training and testing sets?

answers.a: To improve model accuracy by training on more data
answers.b: To evaluate how well the model generalizes to new data
answers.c: To remove incorrect labels from the dataset
answers.d: To increase the number of features

explanations.a: While more training data can improve accuracy, testing data is needed to check generalization.
explanations.b: Correct! A test set helps assess how well the model performs on unseen data.
explanations.c: The dataset split does not modify labels.
explanations.d: Splitting the dataset does not affect the number of features.

questions.question: What does the probability calculation in Naive Bayes depend on?

answers.a: The frequency of words in a given class
answers.b: The order of words in a sentence

explanations.a: Correct! Naive Bayes calculates probabilities based on word frequency within each class.
explanations.b: Naive Bayes does not consider word order.
explanations.c: Sentence length does not directly impact probability calculations in Naive Bayes.
explanations.d: Punctuation marks are usually removed during preprocessing.

questions.question: Which of the following evaluation metrics is NOT used to assess a sentiment analysis model?

explanations.a: Accuracy is a standard metric for classification tasks.
explanations.b: Precision measures how many predicted positives are correct.
explanations.c: Recall measures how many actual positives were correctly identified.
explanations.d: Correct! Execution speed is not an evaluation metric for model performance.

questions.question: If a Naive Bayes classifier predicts a negative review as positive, what type of error is this?

explanations.a: True Positive means a correctly classified positive review.
explanations.b: Correct! A False Positive means the model incorrectly predicted a negative review as positive.
explanations.c: False Negative means a positive review was classified as negative.
explanations.d: True Negative means a correctly classified negative review.
